newsitem.title: USA: ConAgra agrees to pay $8.3 mln fine in grain mishandling case.
newsitem.headline: ConAgra agrees to pay $8.3 mln fine in grain mishandling case.

text.p: ConAgra Inc. pleaded guilty Wednesday to federal charges that its Peavey Co. adulterated, misgraded and misweighed grain at grain elevators and agreed to pay $8.3 million in penalties, ConAgra and the government said.

The Omaha, Neb.-based diversified food company pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court in Terre Haute, Ind., to charges involving 12 small and medium-size grain elevators over a four-year period ending in 1992.
"ConAgra used several schemes to defraud farmers and grain buyers to increase their own grain inventories and profits," the U.S. Agriculture Department said in a statement.

"Soybeans were purposefully misgraded, allowing ConAgra to pay less to the farmer yet sell at higher rates; water was added to grain inventories ... adding to its weight and increasing profits when the grain was sold; and ConAgra significantly misweighed grain being sold to end users ... shipping less grain than for which they were paid," the department said.
In addition, "gratuities" were given to government-licensed grain samplers, who allowed elevator employees to substitute better-quality grain samples for poor-quality grain, the department said.

The penalty included a criminal fine of about $4.4 million, a reimbursement of $450,000 to the U.S. Agriculture Department for unearned storage payments and expenses associated with the investigation, and about $3.45 million as compensation for criminal profits, the department said in a statement.
The $8.3 million penalty is in addition to an earlier civil settlement of more than $2 million that was reached between ConAgra and a group of Indiana farmers, the department said.
The agency said four former ConAgra managers also agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges. The company said no one charged in the case works for Peavey or ConAgra today.
Peavey is an independent operating company and part of ConAgra Trading and Processing Cos., a division of ConAgra.

"We regret the conduct at the facilities involved," Thomas Manuel, president of ConAgra Trading and Processing Cos., said in a statement. "We offer no excuses and we've made it very clear that we do not tolerate such conduct."
ConAgra said it and Peavey have acted to decrease the likelihood of similar problems in the future, and Peavey has put into effect compliance programmes and training for all employees.
ConAgra said it entered into a compliance agreement with the Agriculture Department tha t it said will result in no administrative actions being taken against the company.
The agreement requires the implementation of several compliance programmes at grain elevators. Many of those programmes are already in place.
The Agriculture Department said the charges amounted to violations of the U.S. Grain Standards Act, the U.S. Warehouse Act and the U.S. Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act.
The department said the settlement with ConAgra culminates a four-year investigation by a task force headed by the agency's Office of Inspector General.
ConAgra's stock rose 75 cents to $56.75 in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
